message_1: Consider a conducting wire of length 5 meters in a uniform magnetic field $\vec{B}=(0.2 \hat{i}+0.3 \hat{j}+0.4 \hat{k}) T$. The wire is moving perpendicularly to the magnetic field with a velocity of $\vec{v}=(10\hat{i}+20\hat{j}+30\hat{k}) m/s$. Find the EMF induced in the wire.
message_2:
To find the induced EMF in the wire, we can use the formula:

EMF = $| \vec{v} \times \vec{B} | \cdot L$

where $\vec{v}$ is the velocity of the wire, $\vec{B}$ is the magnetic field, and $L$ is the length of the wire.

First, let's find the cross product of the velocity and magnetic field vectors:

$\vec{v} \times \vec{B} = \begin{vmatrix}
\hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k} \\
10 & 20 & 30 \\
0.2 & 0.3 & 0.4
\end{vmatrix}$

Expanding the determinant, we get:

$\vec{v} \times \vec{B} = (20 \cdot 0.4 - 30 \cdot 0.3) \hat{i} - (10 \cdot 0.4 - 30 \cdot 0.2) \hat{j} + (10 \cdot 0.3 - 20 \cdot 0.2) \hat{k}$

$\vec{v} \times \vec{B} = (8 - 9) \hat{i} - (4 - 6) \hat{j} + (3 - 4) \hat{k}$

$\vec{v} \times \vec{B} = -\hat{i} + 2\hat{j} - \hat{k}$

Now, let's find the magnitude of the cross product:

$| \vec{v} \times \vec{B} | = \sqrt{(-1)^2 + (2)^2 + (-1)^2} = \sqrt{1 + 4 + 1} = \sqrt{6}$

Finally, we can find the induced EMF:

EMF = $| \vec{v} \times \vec{B} | \cdot L = \sqrt{6} \cdot 5 = 5\sqrt{6} V$

So, the induced EMF in the wire is $5\sqrt{6}$ volts.
